name: Yoshito Ohta
content: Yoshito Ohta Yoshito Ohta Professor Control Systems Theory Group Department of Applied Mathematics and Physics Graduate School of Informatics Kyoto University Japanese Page Research Home Biography Research Courses Research interests My research interests include control system design, system identification, and networked control systems. The following are specific topics. Control of power networks The increase of renewable energy sources raise problems for control of power networks. For example, power generation and consumption should be balanced, the voltage and the frequency should be kept within the prescribed range, and the power generation and distribution should be efficiently carried out. The aim of the study is to cope with these problems and to develop control techniques to ensure the quality of electric power in the presence of variable renewable energy. Control of electronic power devices such as grid-tie inverters and DC-DC converters is studied in this research work. We apply robust control techniques and improve control performance of the devices. Grid-tie inverters are a device that sends electrical power generated by photovoltaic (PV) cells or wind firms into AC power transmission line. We design the current control loop appropriately to satisfy the FRT (fault-ride-through) capabilities. DC-DC converters are a device that produces desired DC voltage. We design a controller for DC-DC zeta converters that can function both step-up and step-down operations. The voltage regulation at the connection point is necessary to deal with inverse power flow caused by PV generation. We propose a distributed algorithm to control both active power and reactive power to keep the voltage within the allowable range. The algorithm can be applied to both residential solar systems and PV power plants using a\real-time pricing strategy. System modeling and identification System identification is a fundamental research area studying modeling of dynamical control systems. Currently, a continuous-time system identification method based on system transformation and the Bayesian system identification approach are under investigation. Generalized orthonormal basis functions are a special class of orthonormal basis that induces continuous-time to discrete-time system transformation. This extends to stochastic systems having random processes as inputs and outputs. We propose a continuous-time system identification algorithm based on the transformation. The Bayesian approach is applied to system identification of an FIR (finite impulse response) model. The impulse response is estimated using the maximal likelihood method. Choosing suitable kernels that capture the dynamics of the plant is essential. In this research, we investigate the kernel based on the generalized orthonormal basis functions. Also we study the empirical Bayes approach for the hyper-parameter selection. Networked control The aim of this research is to derive fundamental limitations of networked control systems. Networks are modeled by channels having communication constraints. The main focus of the research is to derive achievable control performances under the given communication constraints. The state estimation problem and the disturbance rejection problem for networked control systems are studied using the information theoretic approach that can handle both Gaussian variables and bounded variables.
